subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the
leading edge
of knowledge and discovery with
parapsychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I’m Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today I’m going to address the question
of what is your boggle threshold, and
what is my boggle threshold?
Boggle: What an interesting word. It’s
like related to mind-boggling.
Where do you draw a line in the sand,
that there’s something
that you will not ever believe.
For example, there was a
great physicist from the 19th Century, [Hermann von Helmholtz, 1821-1894]
who said,
“I’m not going to accept the evidence for
thought transference, telepathy or
extra-sensory perception –
even if all of the members of the Royal
Academy of Science were to testify to it.”
Recently James Alcock, who has been
a guest on the New Thinking Allowed
channel,
published an article in response
to a paper in the American Psychologist –
I’ve referred to
often – it was published in August
2018 summarizing 1,400
experiments in parapsychology with
overwhelmingly
significant statistical odds, that
something is going on here, there is
something happening
when it comes to psi.
That’s a word that parapsychologists
use to cover
everything they study.
So, without even specifying what it is, we
know something is going on.
But Alcock in his response said, “It
doesn’t matter
how many experiments suggest that
something unusual is happening here, it's
impossible. So,
it can’t be true.” So, that was
his boggle-threshold. It was just too
much for him to accept.
And we all have things like that. We
all draw a line
somewhere. Now, I’ll give you an example
of something
I will not accept. And that is – and I hear
it occasionally, in fact
regularly, I hear it from different
visitors
to the website, different people who post
their comments
on the YouTube channel. Basically,
the idea is that there are some people,
some groups
of people on this planet who are morally
superior to other groups; or
who are morally inferior to other groups.
I can tell you right now, I don’t buy it.
Now, you may feel that you’ve got good
evidence. It’s the bankers;
it’s the doctors; it’s the scientists;
it’s the elite; it’s the poor;
it’s the Jews; it’s the Muslims; it’s the
Christians;
it’s the Satanists; it’s the
Anti-Satanists.
As far as I’m concerned, no, there are no
groups of people on the planet that have
an edge on moral superiority or
moral inferiority. That’s my position.
But, and if you try to convince me
otherwise, you are going to have a really
hard time.
But what we really are talking about
here is: where is the evidence?
You see, I report
all kinds of unbelievable things
on this channel. I do. For example,
I know that a few days before this video
is going to be released, is my
interview with William Lyon, an
anthropologist studying Native American
Indian medicine powers. He put it
very bluntly during the interview. He
said, “Nothing is impossible for these
people.
You name it. You know, they can turn into
animals,
if they wish. They can fly.
They can levitate. They can
make spirits appear.” Spirit
materialisations –
we have a couple of recent interviews
about spirit materialisations.
It was only about a week ago when we did
our online PK metal-bending party.
Dozens of people reported
that when they held a fork in their hand
it became soft as putty,
and could use just the tiniest pressure
of their fingertip
and bend it into curlicues,
and then it hardened, and they couldn’t
bend it back.
So, where do you draw the line? What are
you going to believe?
And how? What method are you going to use?
If you subscribe to a viewpoint,
as expressed by Jason Reza Jorjani in
a
recent interview, that we live in a
simulated reality.
That what we think of as external
physical reality is not
much different than the Holodeck on Star
Trek, for example. Then yes,
anything would be possible. If you are
outside, and you can control it, or if you
accept higher dimensions of space that
can control
lower dimensions of space. If you
are a deist
or a theist, and assume that there
are deities or
there is one God who is the
creator and stands outside of this
four-dimensional world we live in.
Then,
for that Being, nothing would be
impossible.
Now, I use this standard: as a
parapsychologist
I am aware of the literature, 140 years
roughly of empirical
data gathering. So, when people talk to me
about
spirit materialisations or spoon-bending
I know that there’s a database I can
refer to
that gives me greater confidence in the
things that are reported. Plus,
because of my own investigations, I have
seen
quite a bit first hand and so I’m
probably much more open
than many people are. But I have my
limits
as well. And not just with regard to
ethics,
because I think it's an ethical question:
Are there groups of people who are
morally superior
or morally inferior?
There are issues concerning, let’s
talk about
aliens. Now, I’ve interviewed several
people who
believe that there are alien races,
people from other universes, or other
planets, or other star systems, living
here on earth,
walking among us. I have to tell you,
I’m interested in their accounts. I
think it's
worthy of being taken seriously, but
I don’t think the evidence is at the
same level as 140 years of empirical
investigations.
The truth is that the field of ufology –
the study of these things – is maybe 50
years old, it goes back
maybe 60 years to the 1940s or so,
at the most. Unless you begin to get into
folklore,
which is very interesting, if we’re
talking about the realm of the
collective unconscious.
But if we’re talking about the physical
presence of
alien beings, I’m open minded but
I don’t see the evidence there yet.
So, here’s a key for me,
and maybe you’ll agree, it’s a good
attitude to take for yourself:
Skepticism is a healthy thing. I
encourage people to be skeptical.
In particular, be skeptical of everything
I say
and be skeptical of everything that you
hold
to be certain because you might just be
wrong. I
have to say, as I read the comments from
viewers,
I hear from many, many viewers who are
certain about this or that, or the other
thing.
I often think to myself – I don’t have
the time to respond to each and every
one of these comments –
what makes you so certain?
Well, I’m inclined to think it may be a
personality type.
Well, I’m not that type of personality
to hold to various facts with stubborn
certainty. I don’t think I am.
I might be self-deceived. But, for the
most part,
what I think is useful is to be
skeptical but
not to be harsh, not to treat
things that I
disagree with a horse laugh, or try
to disparage
other people’s ideas because they’re
different from my own.
I think, and I’ll tell you this – I think
all
ideas and all people
should be treated with respect at all
times.
I honestly do feel that way so I will
respectfully disagree with people but
I certainly am opposed to the kind of
antagonisms
that often occur, especially with
regard to parapsychology. The hostility
at times can be overwhelming. I know, for
example, that J.B.
Rhine, who was an experimental psychologist,
who did card guessing experiments,
was criticized so heavily that
he sought psychiatric help just
to deal with the emotional burden of
people pouncing on him for reporting
his experimental results. I think
that’s
really too bad, but that is the way
of things.
That’s how things are and we live in
a world where there’s lots of conflicts,
and
because, as I’ve already expressed
myself in the monologue on non-duality,
I embrace it all. I do.
But I want to leave you with this
question, the question I started out with:
What is your boggle threshold?
Why do you hold the boggle threshold t
he way you do? Is it time for you to
consider
revising your boggle threshold in any
way?
Thank you for being with me.
[Music]
